name: Gentle Hand Squeeze
steps: Hold both hands out in front of you, palms facing up.
Slowly curl your fingers into soft fists, squeezing gently.
Hold for a moment, then release and spread your fingers wide like a starfish.
Repeat this squeeze and release three more times, nice and slow.
Give your hands a gentle shake to finish. Well done.

name: Shoulder Drop
steps: Take a breath in and lift your shoulders up towards your ears.
Hold them there for just a second.
Now breathe out and let your shoulders drop completely.
Notice how much lighter that feels.
Repeat two more times. You carry a lot, so let some of it go.

name: Ankle Circles
steps: Sit comfortably or hold onto something for balance if standing.
Lift one foot slightly off the ground.
Draw five slow circles with your toes, going one direction.
Now reverse and draw five circles the other way.
Switch to the other foot and repeat both directions.
Place both feet down and feel how much more awake they are.

name: Jaw Release
steps: Let your mouth fall gently open, relaxing your jaw completely.
Place your fingertips on your cheeks and make small circles.
Let your jaw hang loose while you massage for a few seconds.
Slowly close your mouth and notice the difference.
You probably didn't realise how much tension was hiding there.

name: Wrist Loosener
steps: Stretch one arm out and gently pull your fingers back with the other hand.
Hold for a few seconds, feeling a gentle stretch in your wrist.
Now point your fingers down and gently press for a few seconds.
Switch to the other hand and repeat both stretches.
Finish by rolling both wrists in circles a few times. Lovely.

name: Eye Rest
steps: Rub your palms together until they feel warm.
Close your eyes and gently cup your warm palms over them.
Don't press on your eyes, just let the warmth sink in.
Breathe slowly and enjoy the darkness for a few breaths.
When you're ready, slowly remove your hands and blink softly.
Your eyes do so much for you. That was a little thank you to them.

name: Toe Scrunch
steps: With your feet on the floor, scrunch your toes up tight.
Hold for three seconds.
Release and spread your toes as wide as you can.
Repeat this three more times.
It's a tiny movement, but your whole body will thank you.

name: Seated Cat-Cow
steps: Sit on the edge of your chair with your feet flat on the floor.
Place your hands on your knees.
Breathe in and gently arch your back, lifting your chest and looking slightly up.
Breathe out and round your back, tucking your chin towards your chest.
Move slowly between these two positions, following your breath.
Repeat five or six times, letting your spine wake up gently.
Come back to a neutral sitting position when you're done.

name: Gentle Seated Twist
steps: Sit up tall and place your right hand on your left knee.
Place your left hand behind you on the chair or your lower back.
Breathe in to lengthen your spine upwards.
Breathe out and gently twist to the left, looking over your shoulder.
Hold for three slow breaths, going a tiny bit further with each exhale.
Slowly return to centre and repeat on the other side.
Your back has been working hard. This is its moment.

name: Standing Forward Fold
steps: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent.
Take a deep breath in and reach your arms up overhead.
As you breathe out, slowly fold forward from your hips, letting your arms hang.
Don't worry about touching the floor. Just let gravity do the work.
Nod your head gently yes and no to release your neck.
Stay here for a few breaths, swaying gently if that feels nice.
Slowly roll back up to standing, one vertebra at a time.
Stand tall and notice how your back feels. A little kinder, hopefully.

name: Knee-to-Chest Hug
steps: Sit comfortably and lift one knee towards your chest.
Wrap your hands around your shin and give it a gentle hug.
Breathe deeply and feel the stretch in your lower back.
Hold for four slow breaths.
Lower that leg and switch to the other side.
Hold for four slow breaths again.
Sometimes your back just needs a hug from the other direction.

name: Shoulder Blade Squeeze
steps: Sit or stand tall with your arms by your sides.
Imagine you're trying to hold a pencil between your shoulder blades.
Gently squeeze your shoulder blades together and hold for five seconds.
Release slowly and let your shoulders relax forward slightly.
Repeat five times, breathing steadily throughout.
This helps undo all that forward-leaning we do without thinking.

name: Pelvic Tilt
steps: Sit on the edge of your chair with feet flat on the floor.
Gently tilt your pelvis forward so your lower back arches slightly.
Then tilt it backward so your lower back rounds.
Rock slowly between these two positions, like a gentle wave.
Do this eight times, keeping the movement small and soft.
This is one of the kindest things you can do for a tired lower back.

name: Side Reach Stretch
steps: Sit or stand tall and reach your right arm overhead.
Gently lean to the left, feeling a stretch along your right side.
Keep both hips grounded and don't push into any pain.
Hold for three slow breaths.
Come back to centre and switch sides.
Hold the left stretch for three slow breaths too.
Return to centre. Your spine just got a little more space.

name: Finger Tap Wake-Up
steps: Hold your hands in front of you.
Start tapping each fingertip to your thumb, one at a time, going quickly.
Speed up as you get into a rhythm. Pinky, ring, middle, index, and back again.
Now tap all your fingertips on the table or your thighs like rain.
Do this for about fifteen seconds, letting the rhythm energise you.
Stop and notice the tingling in your fingers. Hello, energy.

name: Big Yawn Stretch
steps: Open your mouth wide and fake a big yawn, stretching your arms overhead.
Even if the yawn is fake, your body will respond as if it's real.
Stretch your fingers wide at the top.
Let the stretch ripple all the way down to your toes.
Do it twice more. Real yawns might sneak in, and that's perfect.

name: March in Place
steps: Stand up if you can and begin lifting your knees gently, one at a time.
Keep it slow and quiet, like a gentle march.
Swing your arms softly as you go.
After about twenty seconds, add a little twist at the waist with each step.
Keep going for another twenty seconds.
Slow down gradually and come to a stop.
Even a quiet march can wake up your whole body.

name: Scalp Massage
steps: Place all ten fingertips on your scalp.
Make small circles, pressing gently but firmly.
Work your way from your forehead to the back of your head.
Spend a little extra time on any spots that feel particularly good.
Now move to your temples and make soft circles there.
Finish by running your fingers through your hair (if you have some) a few times.
A little scalp attention goes a long way for waking up a tired brain.

name: Sunrise Arms
steps: Start with your arms hanging by your sides.
Breathe in slowly and raise your arms out to the sides and up overhead, like the sun rising.
Touch your palms together at the top if you can.
Breathe out and slowly lower them back down.
Repeat this four more times, making each one a little bigger.
Imagine you're filling yourself with morning light, even if it's the afternoon.

name: Calf Raises
steps: Stand behind your chair and lightly rest your hands on the back for balance.
Slowly rise up onto your toes, lifting your heels off the ground.
Hold at the top for two seconds.
Lower back down gently.
Repeat ten times, keeping it smooth and steady.
This quietly pumps blood back up through your legs and wakes everything up.

name: Face Scrunch and Release
steps: Scrunch up every part of your face as tightly as you can. Go on, really go for it.
Hold that silly face for five seconds.
Now release everything and let your face go completely soft.
Open your eyes wide and raise your eyebrows high.
Repeat twice more. It might make you laugh, and that's extra energy right there.

name: Cross-Body Taps
steps: Stand or sit comfortably.
Tap your right hand to your left knee, then your left hand to your right knee.
Keep alternating in a steady rhythm.
Do this about fifteen times on each side.
Now try tapping your right hand to your left shoulder, then switch.
Repeat fifteen times on each side.
This cross-body movement wakes up both sides of your brain. Clever, right?

name: Neck Release
steps: Sit or stand comfortably and let your shoulders drop.
Slowly tilt your head to the right, bringing your ear towards your shoulder.
Hold for three slow breaths, feeling the gentle stretch.
Bring your head back to centre.
Now tilt to the left and hold for three slow breaths.
Gently drop your chin to your chest and hold for two breaths.
Slowly roll your head in a half-circle from one side to the other.
Return to centre. Your neck works so hard. It deserves that kindness.

name: Progressive Fist Clench
steps: Make tight fists with both hands and hold for five seconds.
Release and notice the feeling of letting go.
Now tense your forearms and fists together. Hold for five seconds.
Release. Feel the tension drain away.
Add your upper arms to the tension. Hold for five seconds.
Release everything at once and let your arms hang loose.
Sometimes you need to tense up on purpose to truly let go.

name: Ear Pull
steps: Gently take hold of both your earlobes between your thumbs and forefingers.
Pull them softly downward and hold for a few seconds.
Move your fingers to the middle of your ears and pull gently outward.
Now move to the top of your ears and pull gently upward.
Finish by rubbing your whole ear between your fingers.
Ears hold a surprising amount of tension. Doesn't that feel better?

name: Butterfly Hug
steps: Cross your arms over your chest, hands resting on opposite shoulders.
Close your eyes if that feels comfortable.
Gently tap your right hand, then your left, alternating slowly.
Keep this gentle rhythm going, like butterfly wings.
Continue for about thirty seconds, breathing naturally.
This simple movement tells your nervous system it's safe to relax.

name: Hand Massage
steps: Take your right hand and press your left thumb into the palm of it.
Make slow circles, working from the centre outward.
Gently squeeze and pull each finger, one at a time.
Press into the fleshy part between your thumb and index finger.
Now switch and give your other hand the same treatment.
Your hands do so much. They deserve a little attention back.

name: Whole Body Squeeze
steps: Take a deep breath in.
As you breathe in, tense every muscle you can think of. Fists, arms, shoulders, face, legs, toes.
Hold everything tight for five seconds.
Now breathe out and release absolutely everything at once.
Let yourself go completely floppy, like a ragdoll.
Repeat twice more. Each time you release, you let go of a little more tension.

name: Tongue and Jaw Release
steps: Press your tongue firmly against the roof of your mouth for five seconds.
Release and let your tongue rest heavily in the bottom of your mouth.
Open your mouth wide and move your jaw gently side to side.
Close your mouth and let your teeth part slightly so your jaw hangs loose.
Take three breaths with your jaw completely relaxed.
We hold so much tension here without realising. Not anymore.

name: Self-Hug
steps: Wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a proper hug.
Squeeze gently and hold it.
Take a slow, deep breath in through your nose.
Breathe out slowly through your mouth.
Stay here for a few more breaths. You deserve kindness, especially from yourself.
When you're ready, gently release and place your hands in your lap.

name: Warm Hands on Heart
steps: Rub your palms together until they feel warm.
Place one hand over your heart and the other on top of it.
Close your eyes and feel the warmth spreading into your chest.
Notice your heartbeat beneath your hands. It's been beating for you all day.
Take five slow, deep breaths while keeping your hands here.
Whisper or think something kind to yourself. Anything at all.
When you're ready, gently lower your hands. That warmth stays with you.

name: Grounding Touch
steps: Place both feet flat on the floor and press down gently.
Feel the ground supporting you. It's solid and it's here.
Run your hands slowly along your thighs, noticing the texture.
Touch something nearby: a table, a cushion, your sleeve. Notice how it feels.
Name three things you can feel right now, quietly in your mind.
Take a deep breath. You are here. You are real. That is enough.

name: Gentle Rocking
steps: Sit comfortably and let your body begin to rock very gently, side to side.
Keep the movement small and slow, like a boat on calm water.
Let your arms and hands rest wherever feels natural.
Close your eyes if you'd like. There's nowhere you need to be right now.
Continue rocking gently for about forty seconds.
Slowly come to stillness when you're ready.
Rocking is how we've been comforted since we were small. It still works.

name: Kind Hands
steps: Hold one of your hands gently in the other, as if it belongs to someone you love.
Stroke the back of your hand slowly with your thumb.
Notice the texture of your skin, the shape of your fingers.
Take a slow breath and think of one thing you did today that was kind.
It doesn't have to be big. It counts because you did it.
Give your hand a gentle squeeze. You are doing your best, and that is plenty.

name: Comfort Breathing
steps: Place one hand on your belly and one on your chest.
Breathe in slowly for four counts, feeling your belly rise first, then your chest.
Hold gently for two counts.
Breathe out for six counts, letting your chest fall, then your belly.
Repeat this four more times.
With each exhale, imagine breathing out some of the heaviness you're carrying.
It's okay to feel what you're feeling. This breath is here to help you through it.

name: Warm Face Hold
steps: Rub your hands together to warm them up.
Gently cup your face in your warm hands, covering your cheeks.
Close your eyes and let the warmth settle in.
Take three slow, deep breaths.
On each exhale, soften your face a little more under your hands.
You are held. Even if it's just by your own two hands, it counts.

name: Five-Minute Full Reset
steps: Find a comfortable position, sitting or standing, wherever you are.
For the first minute, close your eyes and take ten slow, deep breaths. Count each one.
For the second minute, gently roll your head, shoulders, and wrists in slow circles.
For the third minute, stand and stretch gently in any way that feels good. Reach up, fold forward, twist softly.
For the fourth minute, sit back down and place your hands on your knees. Breathe naturally and listen to whatever sounds are around you.
For the final minute, think of one thing you're looking forward to, even something small like a cup of tea.
Open your eyes and return gently. You just gave yourself a real break. That matters.

name: Body Scan
steps: Settle into a comfortable position and close your eyes.
Start at the top of your head. Notice any sensations there. No need to change anything, just notice.
Move your attention slowly down through your face, jaw, neck, and shoulders. Breathe into any tight spots.
Continue down through your arms, hands, and fingers. Let them soften.
Bring your attention to your chest and belly. Feel them rise and fall.
Move through your hips, thighs, knees, and calves. Let each part feel heavy and relaxed.
Finish at your feet and toes. Wiggle them gently.
Take three deep breaths and open your eyes when you're ready. You just checked in with your whole self.

name: Seated Yoga Flow
steps: Sit comfortably and close your eyes. Take five deep breaths to settle in.
Reach your arms overhead on an inhale, then fold forward on an exhale, hands reaching for the floor. Hold for three breaths.
Sit back up and do five rounds of seated cat-cow: arch your back as you inhale, round it as you exhale.
Place your right hand on your left knee and twist gently to the left. Hold for three breaths. Switch sides.
Reach your right arm overhead and lean to the left for a side stretch. Hold for three breaths. Switch sides.
Interlace your fingers behind your back and lift your chest, opening your shoulders. Hold for three breaths.
Return to sitting tall. Place your hands on your knees and take ten slow breaths.
Open your eyes. You just did yoga in a chair, and it was beautiful.

name: Mindful Senses
steps: Sit or stand comfortably and take three settling breaths.
For one minute, look around and notice five things you can see. Really look at their colours, shapes, and textures.
For the next minute, close your eyes and listen. Notice four different sounds, near or far.
Now notice three things you can feel: the chair beneath you, air on your skin, fabric on your body.
Notice two things you can smell. If nothing stands out, notice the absence of smell.
Finally, notice one taste in your mouth, even if it's just neutral.
Take a few deep breaths. You just brought yourself completely into the present moment.
The present moment is the only one where rest is possible. Well done for arriving here.

name: Gentle Standing Sequence
steps: Stand comfortably with feet hip-width apart. Close your eyes and take five deep breaths.
Slowly raise your arms overhead, reaching as high as feels good. Hold for three breaths, then lower.
Fold gently forward, bending your knees as much as you need. Let your head hang heavy. Sway gently for thirty seconds.
Roll up slowly. Then do ten slow calf raises, lifting and lowering your heels.
Place your hands on your hips and make five slow circles with your hips in each direction.
Finish with one minute of standing still, eyes closed, hands by your sides, breathing naturally.
Open your eyes. You just gave your whole body five minutes of care.

name: Compassion Pause
steps: Find a quiet spot and sit comfortably. Place both hands over your heart.
For the first minute, breathe slowly and feel your heartbeat. You've been going all day, so just be still.
For the second minute, think of someone you care for. Picture their face and silently wish them peace.
For the third minute, turn that same kindness towards yourself. You are doing something important and difficult.
For the fourth minute, gently stretch your neck, shoulders, and hands while continuing to breathe deeply.
For the final minute, sit with your hands in your lap, palms up, and simply breathe.
When you're ready, open your eyes. Caring for others starts with moments like this one.

name: Stretch and Breathe Flow
steps: Begin seated. Take five deep breaths to arrive in this moment.
Interlace your fingers and push your palms towards the ceiling. Stretch tall for three breaths.
Release and do gentle neck circles: three in one direction, three in the other.
Extend one leg at a time and flex and point your foot five times each. Circle your ankles too.
Stand up slowly. Shake out your hands, arms, and legs for about thirty seconds. Be playful with it.
Do five slow shoulder rolls forward, then five backward.
Place your hand on a wall and do a gentle calf stretch on each side for thirty seconds.
Return to sitting and rest quietly for the final minute, breathing naturally. This break was well earned.

name: Box Breathing
steps: Sit comfortably and let your shoulders relax.
Breathe in slowly through your nose for four counts.
Hold your breath gently for four counts. No straining.
Breathe out slowly through your mouth for four counts.
Hold the empty breath for four counts.
Repeat this box pattern three more times.
Each side of the box brings a little more calm. You've just drawn four of them.

name: Extended Exhale
steps: Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you'd like.
Breathe in through your nose for a count of three.
Now breathe out through your mouth for a count of six.
The longer exhale tells your body it's time to calm down.
Repeat this five more times, keeping the rhythm gentle.
If six feels too long, try breathing out for four or five. Find what works for you.

name: Bee Breath
steps: Sit comfortably and gently close your eyes.
Take a deep breath in through your nose.
As you breathe out, hum softly, like a bee. Keep it quiet and gentle.
Feel the vibration in your throat and chest.
Take another breath in and hum again on the exhale.
Repeat four more times. The humming is surprisingly soothing.
When you stop, sit quietly and notice the calm that hum has created.

name: Counting Breath
steps: Sit comfortably and close your eyes.
Breathe naturally and begin counting each exhale. One, two, three...
If your mind wanders (and it will, that's completely normal), gently start back at one.
Try to reach ten without losing count.
If you reach ten, start again from one.
Continue for about a minute. There's no failing here, only returning.
Open your eyes. Every time you came back to counting, you practised being present.

name: Balloon Breath
steps: Place your hands on your belly.
Imagine your belly is a balloon. Breathe in slowly and fill the balloon up.
Feel your hands rise as your belly expands.
Now breathe out slowly and feel the balloon deflate, hands moving inward.
Repeat this five times, making the balloon a little bigger each time.
This is a lovely one to do anytime you need to slow things down.

name: Cooling Breath
steps: Sit comfortably and relax your shoulders.
Curl your tongue slightly, or if you can't do that, make a small O shape with your lips.
Breathe in slowly through your curled tongue or lips, feeling the cool air.
Close your mouth and breathe out through your nose.
Repeat five more times.
This gently cools and calms your whole system. A mini reset for a busy mind.

name: Sigh It Out
steps: Take a deep breath in through your nose, filling your lungs completely.
Open your mouth and let it all out with a big, audible sigh. Ahhhhh.
Don't hold back. Let the sigh be as dramatic as it wants to be.
Take another deep breath in.
Sigh it out again, even bigger this time.
Do this three more times. Sighing is your body's natural way of releasing stress. Let it do its thing.
